currentDoc:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion,

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put thier own safety at risk to aide you becuase of an eaccident, then I beleive you have crossed a line.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

currentDoc:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily

currentDoc:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases resuce teams have to venture

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, eve

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times,

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators , or even

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver. Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators , or even the general public, due to the hazzardness of the

currentDoc:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators , or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity.

If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators , or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity., free clibin

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity., free climbing and base jumping can i

currentDoc:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity., free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below.

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity., free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem. If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity, free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below, avalanche

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity, free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below, skiing off t

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

currentDoc:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity, free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below, skiing off the track

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity, free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below, skiing off the track can cause avla

currentDoc:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity, free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below, skiing off the track can cause avalanches.

If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity, free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below, skiing off the track can cause avalanches.  Thhere is

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity, free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below, skiing off the track can cause avalanches.  Thhere is nothing wrong with extreme

currentDoc:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity, free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below, skiing off the track can cause avalanches.  There is nothing wrong with extreme sports, but the participant

Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity, free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below, skiing off the track can cause avalanches.  There is nothing wrong with extreme sports, but the participant should demonstrate responsibility not to put others in danger, or to rescue the person themselves if necessary, or at the very least insure adequate safety precautions. In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity, free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below, skiing off the track can cause avalanches.  There is nothing wrong with extreme sports, but the participant should demonstrate responsibility not to put others in danger, or to rescue the person themselves if necessary, or at the very least insure adequate safety precautions.  Therefore, whether it is selfish depe

There is nothing wrong with extreme sports, but the participant should demonstrate responsibility not to put others in danger, or to rescue the person themselves if necessary, or at the very least insure adequate safety precautions.  Therefore, whether it is selfish depends on the person, not

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem. There is nothing wrong with extreme sports, but the participant should demonstrate responsibility not to put others in danger, or to rescue the person themselves if necessary, or at the very least insure adequate safety precautions.  Therefore, whether it is selfish depends on the person, not the sport.  It is onl

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily

If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity, free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below, skiing off the track can cause avalanches.  There is nothing wrong with extreme sports, but the participant should demonstrate responsibility not to put others in danger, or to rescue the person themselves if necessary, or at the very least insure adequate safety precautions.  Therefore, whether it is selfish depends on the person, not the sport.  It is only selfish to pursue,

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Therefore, whether it is selfish depends on the person, not the sport.  It is only selfish to pursue, if you actions in do

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, the decision about sports is a personal one.  The issue arises if you endanger others in pursuit of your sport.  If you are endangering people not involved, or if rescuers have to put their own safety at risk to aide you because of an accident, then I believe you have crossed a line.   n the other hand, if it is just your own risk and only your own choice to endanger yourself, I don't think that's necessarily
 a problem.  There are times when people go hiking and climbing in inclement weather and get stranded, In those cases rescue teams have to venture into the same danger, but they have not made that choice, aside from signing on to be a life saver.  Other times, these sports can put at risk spectators, or even the general public, due to the hazardousness of the activity, free climbing and base jumping can imperil those below, skiing off the track can cause avalanches.  There is nothing wrong with extreme sports, but the participant should demonstrate responsibility not to put others in danger, or to rescue the person themselves if necessary, or at the very least insure adequate safety precautions.  Therefore, whether it is selfish depends on the person, not the sport.  It is only selfish to pursue, if you actions in doi
